Part II The Concept of Domestic Jurisdiction in United Nations Practice
The Basic Policy to Be Applied to Domestic Jurisdiction Questions
2. Claims Made against the Jurisdiction of the United Nations
A. Claims Relating to the Concept of Domestic Jurisdiction in General International Law
A. That there are certain fixed topics always within the domestic jurisdiction
B. That all topics about which no formal international obligations exist automatically fall within the domestic jurisdiction of a state
B. Claims Relating Specifically to Article 2 (7)
A. That Article 2 (7) is an overriding provision, to which all Charter articles are subject, save for the express exception contained therein
B. That all states have the right to decide whether a specific topic falls within their domestic jurisdiction
C. That certain defined actions constitute an 'intervention'
D. That the question whether or not a topic is a matter of domestic jurisdiction is an 'important' or 'substantive' question
E. That the term 'essentially' means 'by and large', thus differing from the term 'solely'
3. Claims in Support of the Jurisdiction of the United Nations
A. Claims Relating to the Concept of Domestic Jurisdiction in General International Law
A. That emphasis must be placed on the developing and relative nature of the principle of domestic jurisdiction
B. That jurisdiction may be assumed on the grounds of 'international concern'
A. That 'intervention' can only occur where the resolution concerning a matter of domestic jurisdiction is addressed to a particular state
B. That the United Nations may always act where treaty rights and duties are involved
C. That the Security Council is not bound by the reservation in Article 2 (7) when it is acting under Chapter VII
D. That the United Nations may always act where a question of self-determination is involved
E. That a reservation of domestic jurisdiction is inapplicable where United Nations action is occurring within a country at its own request
F. That the General Assembly has authority to determine the territories to which Chapter XI of the Charter applies
G. That the United Nations is entitled to request political information on Non-Self-Governing Territories under Article 73 (e)
H. That the Economic and Social Council has authority to convene conferences of Representatives of Non-Self-Governing Territories
J. That the General Assembly may assume jurisdiction where human rights are involved
